paragraphs.text:
%md
## CONTEXT

msg.data: CONTEXT

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Main question

msg.data: Main question

paragraphs.text:
%md
Is there a correlation between the national happiness of a country and the proportion of votes of extreme political parties?

msg.data: Is there a correlation between the national happiness of a country and the proportion of votes of extreme political parties?

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Center pieces of our study

msg.data: Center pieces of our study

paragraphs.text:
%md
- World happiness report (HI index)

In July 2011, the UN General Assembly adopted "resolution 65/309 Happiness: Towards a Holistic Definition of Development" inviting member countries to measure the happiness of their people and to use the data to help guide public policy. This was the inception of a report that started being issued soon after, pulling the trigger of a whole new approach for the countries to tackle the measurement of their development with a term like the gross national happiness in lieu of using the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as the baseline.

In the reports, experts in fields including economics, psychology, survey analysis, and national statistics, describe how measurements of well-being can be used effectively to assess the progress of nations, and other topics. Each report is organized by chapters that delve deeper into issues relating to happiness feeling of a nation. In particular, the chapter that then are grouped into few measurements to determine the index are the following: (1) business & economic, (2) citizen engagement, (3) communications & technology, (4) diversity (social issues), (5) education & families, (6) emotions (well-being), (7) environment & energy, (8) food & shelter, (9) government and politics, (10) law & order (safety), (11) health, (12) religion and ethics, (13) transportation, and (14) work.

Then these parts are reduced to few dimensions that converge into an index, which is the happiness index score.

msg.data:
• World happiness report (HI index)

In July 2011, the UN General Assembly adopted “resolution 65/309 Happiness: Towards a Holistic Definition of Development” inviting member countries to measure the happiness of their people and to use the data to help guide public policy. This was the inception of a report that started being issued soon after, pulling the trigger of a whole new approach for the countries to tackle the measurement of their development with a term like the gross national happiness in lieu of using the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as the baseline.

In the reports, experts in fields including economics, psychology, survey analysis, and national statistics, describe how measurements of well-being can be used effectively to assess the progress of nations, and other topics. Each report is organized by chapters that delve deeper into issues relating to happiness feeling of a nation. In particular, the chapter that then are grouped into few measurements to determine the index are the following: (1) business & economic, (2) citizen engagement, (3) communications & technology, (4) diversity (social issues), (5) education & families, (6) emotions (well-being), (7) environment & energy, (8) food & shelter, (9) government and politics, (10) law & order (safety), (11) health, (12) religion and ethics, (13) transportation, and (14) work.

Then these parts are reduced to few dimensions that converge into an index, which is the happiness index score.

paragraphs.text:
%md
- National elections and the categorization of the political parties

msg.data: • National elections and the categorization of the political parties

paragraphs.text:
%md
We decided to relate the happiness with the votes given by the inhabitants able to vote, to extremist political parties. We also delmited the scope of the research to the UE and in particular
to a sample of 10 countries. Further work can be done to extend the scope to more countries, not only from UE but to other regions.


Classification of political parties to a place in the ideology spectrum

We need to say that the study is subject to subjective criteria in how we have considered political parties extremists or not. In general, there is the political spectrum concept and specialized webpages follow this classification in order to assign political parties to a place in that spectrum. However, in some cases, it is very difficult to draw a line and leave a party in one side or the other. In those cases, where we have faced inconclusive classification, we decided how to classify them. For instance, Syriza in Greece (a catch-all party now with the strong left tilt that initially was believed to be radical left but has smoothed down relatively with the time to gather more voters) and Unidas Podemos in Spain.

msg.data:
We decided to relate the happiness with the votes given by the inhabitants able to vote, to extremist political parties. We also delmited the scope of the research to the UE and in particular
to a sample of 10 countries. Further work can be done to extend the scope to more countries, not only from UE but to other regions.

Classification of political parties to a place in the ideology spectrum

We need to say that the study is subject to subjective criteria in how we have considered political parties extremists or not. In general, there is the political spectrum concept and specialized webpages follow this classification in order to assign political parties to a place in that spectrum. However, in some cases, it is very difficult to draw a line and leave a party in one side or the other. In those cases, where we have faced inconclusive classification, we decided how to classify them. For instance, Syriza in Greece (a catch-all party now with the strong left tilt that initially was believed to be radical left but has smoothed down relatively with the time to gather more voters) and Unidas Podemos in Spain.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## DATA

msg.data: DATA

paragraphs.text:
%md

Data has been collected from different sources. Happiness report from both web scrapping and csv available in the web. The national election results is of primary source since we have collected data from different places to build a csv from scratch with just the information and categories we needed.

In particular, HI 2018 data was taken by doing web scrapping in wikipedia, more details on how it was performed can be found in "1. Happiness report web scrapping 2018.ipynb". Then we took the rest of info from the csv reports themselves for the rest of the years where the report is available (it was created in 2011).

msg.data:
Data has been collected from different sources. Happiness report from both web scrapping and csv available in the web. The national election results is of primary source since we have collected data from different places to build a csv from scratch with just the information and categories we needed.

In particular, HI 2018 data was taken by doing web scrapping in wikipedia, more details on how it was performed can be found in “1. Happiness report web scrapping 2018.ipynb”. Then we took the rest of info from the csv reports themselves for the rest of the years where the report is available (it was created in 2011).

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Data cleaning

msg.data: Data cleaning

paragraphs.text:
%md
As per the happiness report, since the source was different we found differences in them, so the cleaning part had to be adapted accordingly. In any case, the common denominator was that we needed to select the countries we wanted out of the total of countries of the report. We also renamed and dropped empty columns, correct incorrect naming of countries, reordering columns to make it more easily readable, putting it all to lower case for consistency and to enable further merges and groupings. Finally we created dataframes to then merge in the same way that the tables were conceived initially in the database, and we concatenated the tables to have them all in the same dataframe. 
As per the elections results, since it is primary source, the needed for cleaning was minimum. We reorganize the columns, dropped NaN and not needed ones and replace some incorrect strings by correct values. At the end we put all the results in the same structure and in the same dataframe.

More details can be found in "2. Data Cleaning.ipynb".

msg.data:
As per the happiness report, since the source was different we found differences in them, so the cleaning part had to be adapted accordingly. In any case, the common denominator was that we needed to select the countries we wanted out of the total of countries of the report. We also renamed and dropped empty columns, correct incorrect naming of countries, reordering columns to make it more easily readable, putting it all to lower case for consistency and to enable further merges and groupings. Finally we created dataframes to then merge in the same way that the tables were conceived initially in the database, and we concatenated the tables to have them all in the same dataframe.
As per the elections results, since it is primary source, the needed for cleaning was minimum. We reorganize the columns, dropped NaN and not needed ones and replace some incorrect strings by correct values. At the end we put all the results in the same structure and in the same dataframe.

More details can be found in “2. Data Cleaning.ipynb”.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Database creation and seeding

msg.data: Database creation and seeding

paragraphs.text:
%md
Once we defined the data we wanted to extract from the happiness reports and the one we needed from the elections, we created a database to store all the data. In particular we used a Google cloud database.
After the database was created and data all cleaned in an aligned way with the database structure, we inserted all data at once to our database. More details in the code used can be found as well in "4. Database_creation_seeding.ipynb". In the same way, tables, columns and keys can be found in "5. DB_diagram.png".

msg.data:
Once we defined the data we wanted to extract from the happiness reports and the one we needed from the elections, we created a database to store all the data. In particular we used a Google cloud database.
After the database was created and data all cleaned in an aligned way with the database structure, we inserted all data at once to our database. More details in the code used can be found as well in “4. Database_creation_seeding.ipynb”. In the same way, tables, columns and keys can be found in “5. DB_diagram.png”.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## STUDY RESULTS

msg.data: STUDY RESULTS

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Initial Hypothesis

msg.data: Initial Hypothesis

paragraphs.text:
%md
The initial thought was that people in countries that are less happy will have a tendency to vote extreme political parties:

“There will be a negative correlation between extremism (both left and right) and the happiness of a country”

msg.data:
The initial thought was that people in countries that are less happy will have a tendency to vote extreme political parties:

“There will be a negative correlation between extremism (both left and right) and the happiness of a country”

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Results

msg.data: Results

paragraphs.text:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

df_countries = pd.read_csv("../Data/countries.csv")
df_happiness = pd.read_csv("../Data/happiness_all_constant.csv")
df_elections = pd.read_csv("../Data/Elections_10_countries.csv")
df_happiness = df_happiness[df_happiness["Year"] > 2010]

paragraphs.title: Extreme Party Vote Proportion vs. Happiness Index
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT df_happiness.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_happiness.Score Score, df_elections.proportion_votes Votes, df_elections.extreme_type Extreme_type  FROM df_happiness JOIN df_countries ON df_happiness.id_country = df_countries.id JOIN df_elections ON df_happiness.id_country = df_elections.id_country AND df_happiness.year = df_elections.year

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Our main scatterplot shows the relationship between the happiness score of a country and the vote proportion of extreme political parties grouped by all sampled countries. The size of the points reflects the proportion of votes, the greater the vote concentration in extremists political parties.
We can observe a slight negative correlation in the plot that backs up our initial hypothesis, that is, whenever the national feeling of happiness of one country moves down, the proportion of the total votes in elections tend to increasingly swerve towards extremist parties.

msg.data:
Our main scatterplot shows the relationship between the happiness score of a country and the vote proportion of extreme political parties grouped by all sampled countries. The size of the points reflects the proportion of votes, the greater the vote concentration in extremists political parties.
We can observe a slight negative correlation in the plot that backs up our initial hypothesis, that is, whenever the national feeling of happiness of one country moves down, the proportion of the total votes in elections tend to increasingly swerve towards extremist parties.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Digging a little deeper into the graph above, we can have more insights by looking at each country individually, that is, we chose to show the change of the happiness index over time in the individual countries and compare that to the results of the elections in given countries over the timeframe.
Here, it is important to notice that every country has different tendencies in the political spectrum. We also notice that we have a very small sample of election results, which leads to a lower significance of our analysis.
The analysis was carried out on all ten countries of our initial research.  For representation purposes, we will breakdown the results we obtained for the countries of Austria and Belgium, which we grouped into one graph as the results are very similar. This example best represents our hypothesis (for further results, please see the Appendix at the end of the file).

This example best represents our hypothesis (for further results, please see the Appendix at the end of the file).

%md
## <center>Austria & Belgium</center>

%sql

SELECT df_happiness.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_happiness.Score Score FROM df_happiness JOIN df_countries ON df_happiness.id_country = df_countries.id WHERE Country = "Austria" OR Country = "Belgium"

Year	Country	Votes	Extreme_type
2013	Austria	1.0	Left
2013	Austria	20.5	Right
2017	Austria	0.8	Left
2017	Austria	26.0	Right
2014	Belgium	1.33	Left
2014	Belgium	2.67	Right
2019	Belgium	8.0	Left
2019	Belgium	12.0	Right

paragraphs.text:
%md
In the graphics above, we see the trend that is described in our hypothesis. Our assumption is, that the initial drop of happiness, from 2013 to 2014 and the remaining lowered level, has led to a change in the proportion, remaining low after that point. When we compare that timeframe to the election results, we see that after that decrease in 2014, for the next elections the proportion of extreme votes has risen in relation to the previous ones.

msg.data: In the graphics above, we see the trend that is described in our hypothesis. Our assumption is, that the initial drop of happiness, from 2013 to 2014 and the remaining lowered level, has led to a change in the proportion, remaining low after that point. When we compare that timeframe to the election results, we see that after that decrease in 2014, for the next elections the proportion of extreme votes has risen in relation to the previous ones.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Breaking down correlations between happiness components and extreme political party vote proportion

msg.data: Breaking down correlations between happiness components and extreme political party vote proportion

paragraphs.text:
%python

happiness = pd.merge(df_happiness, df_countries, how ="left", left_on='id_country', right_on='id')
happiness = happiness.rename(columns = {"Year":"year"})
del happiness["id"]

paragraphs.title: Sweden
paragraphs.text:
%python
sweden = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Sweden"]
sweden = sweden.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del sweden["id_country"]
sweden = sweden.groupby("year").sum()
sweden = sweden.drop([2011, 2012, 2015, 2016]).reset_index()
sweden = sweden.replace(0,np.nan)
sweden["proportion_votes"] = sweden["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
sweden_corr = sweden.corr(method="pearson")
sweden_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.title: Spain
paragraphs.text:
%python
spain = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Spain"]
spain = spain.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del spain["id_country"]
spain = spain.groupby("year").sum()
spain = spain.drop([2012, 2013, 2014, 2017]).reset_index()
spain = spain.replace(0,np.nan)
spain["proportion_votes"][3] = 21.08
spain["proportion_votes"] = spain["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
spain_corr = spain.corr(method="pearson")
spain_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.text:
%md
Since the negative correlation is far from being perfect, we have also broken down the components of the world happiness report, in order to be able to better understand why our hypothesis is not being fulfilled. 

Let's take a look at Sweden, we can see that their score correlates positively with the extremist proportion of votes. To cast some light here, let's take a look at the GDP. It correlates almost perfectly with the extreme voting, our theory is that whenever GDP is growing, in general people tend to want to protect it before what they consider outside threatens, so this, along with other protectionist ideas, lures them into veering right and vote for nationalist parties that highlight the protection of the national interests.

Taking another look at the correlation table, Spain gives us insight worth to mention. As the perception of corruption and loss of confidence in the government worsens, the veer towards extremists parties increase, in particular, towards the left. This coincides with the rise of Unidas Podemos over the last year. They were the first challengers of the classical bipartidism PP-PSOE.

msg.data:
Since the negative correlation is far from being perfect, we have also broken down the components of the world happiness report, in order to be able to better understand why our hypothesis is not being fulfilled.

Let’s take a look at Sweden, we can see that their score correlates positively with the extremist proportion of votes. To cast some light here, let’s take a look at the GDP. It correlates almost perfectly with the extreme voting, our theory is that whenever GDP is growing, in general people tend to want to protect it before what they consider outside threatens, so this, along with other protectionist ideas, lures them into veering right and vote for nationalist parties that highlight the protection of the national interests.

Taking another look at the correlation table, Spain gives us insight worth to mention. As the perception of corruption and loss of confidence in the government worsens, the veer towards extremists parties increase, in particular, towards the left. This coincides with the rise of Unidas Podemos over the last year. They were the first challengers of the classical bipartidism PP-PSOE.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Future possible developments

msg.data: Future possible developments

paragraphs.text:
%md
As we now have a basic analysis done, it would be interesting to keep developing this research to obtain a more significant and well-rounded result.
This could be done in a number of ways; however, we do have to consider that we only have data official and consistent data from 2011 onwards. The following two where our suggestions as they peaked our interest the most:

-    A further analysis including all European countries (more data), with more election results. We could, for example, extract results form more than one type of elections (provincial, parliamentary, etc.) to obtain data from more years. Added to this we could consider other factors, such as immigration flow, rise in nationalism, and government investment into national resources to obtain a fuller image of the environment and reduce the variables we do not control.

-    Similarly, to the above suggestion, the research method could be applied to a global sample. Taking into consideration not only the rise of extremism, but also different political systems.

msg.data:
As we now have a basic analysis done, it would be interesting to keep developing this research to obtain a more significant and well-rounded result.
This could be done in a number of ways; however, we do have to consider that we only have data official and consistent data from 2011 onwards. The following two where our suggestions as they peaked our interest the most:

  • A further analysis including all European countries (more data), with more election results. We could, for example, extract results form more than one type of elections (provincial, parliamentary, etc.) to obtain data from more years. Added to this we could consider other factors, such as immigration flow, rise in nationalism, and government investment into national resources to obtain a fuller image of the environment and reduce the variables we do not control.

  • Similarly, to the above suggestion, the research method could be applied to a global sample. Taking into consideration not only the rise of extremism, but also different political systems.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Conclusions

msg.data: Conclusions

paragraphs.text:
%md
Our main conclusion is that there is an observable correlation between the two factors, proving our hypothesis correct.
However, as previously mentioned, we do not have enough data on elections over the years to make a firm conclusion on the matter (high correlations might be due to a small sample size).
It is also important to note, that the topic chosen is very susceptible to exterior variables that are not included in our analysis, so further research and data is needed to be able to reproduce more reliable results.

msg.data:
Our main conclusion is that there is an observable correlation between the two factors, proving our hypothesis correct.
However, as previously mentioned, we do not have enough data on elections over the years to make a firm conclusion on the matter (high correlations might be due to a small sample size).
It is also important to note, that the topic chosen is very susceptible to exterior variables that are not included in our analysis, so further research and data is needed to be able to reproduce more reliable results.

paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT df_happiness.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_happiness.Score Score FROM df_happiness JOIN df_countries ON df_happiness.id_country = df_countries.id WHERE Country = "Italy"

paragraphs.title: Extreme Party Vote Proportion
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT df_elections.year Year, df_countries.country Country, df_elections.proportion_votes Votes, df_elections.extreme_type  Extreme_type FROM df_elections JOIN df_countries ON df_elections.id_country = df_countries.id WHERE Country = "Italy"

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### More broken down correlations

msg.data: More broken down correlations

paragraphs.title: Austria
paragraphs.text:
austria = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Austria"]
austria = austria.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del austria["id_country"]
austria = austria.groupby("year").sum()
austria = austria.replace(0,np.nan)
austria = austria.drop([2011, 2014, 2015, 2018]).reset_index()
austria["proportion_votes"] = austria["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
austria_corr = austria.corr(method="pearson")
austria_corr["proportion_votes"]

msg.data:

GDP                                  0.002270
Social support                      -0.057459

Generosity                          -0.260080
Perceptions of corruption           -0.458034
Confidence in national government    0.103875
proportion_votes                     1.000000

paragraphs.title: Denmark
paragraphs.text:
%python
denmark = happiness[happiness["country"] == "Denmark"]
denmark = denmark.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del denmark["id_country"]
denmark = denmark.groupby("year").sum()
denmark = denmark.drop([2011, 2012, 2013, 2016, 2017]).reset_index()
denmark = denmark.replace(0,np.nan)
denmark["proportion_votes"][3] = 18.43
denmark["proportion_votes"] = denmark["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1)
denmark_corr = denmark.corr(method="pearson")
denmark_corr["proportion_votes"]

paragraphs.title: France

%python
france = happiness[happiness["country"] == "France"]
france = france.merge(df_elections, how="left", on=["id_country", "year"])
del france["id_country"]
france = france.groupby("year").sum()
france = france.drop([2013, 2014, 2015, 2018]).reset_index()
france = france.replace(0,np.nan)
france["proportion_votes"] = france["proportion_votes"].bfill(limit=1).ffill(limit=1)
france_corr = france.corr(method="pearson")
france_corr["proportion_votes"]
